sn2.20:1.1: Standing to one side, the god Anāthapiṇḍika recited these verses in the Buddha’s presence:
sn2.20:2.2: frequented by the Saṅgha of seers,
sn2.20:2.3: where the King of Dhamma stayed:
sn2.20:4.4: and thus be purified in it.
sn2.20:5.3: Even a mendicant who has crossed over
sn2.20:6.1: This is what the god Anāthapiṇḍika said.
sn2.20:6.2: Then he bowed and respectfully circled the Buddha, keeping him on his right side, before vanishing right there.
sn2.20:7.1: Then, when the night had passed, the Buddha addressed the mendicants:
sn2.20:7.2: “Mendicants, tonight, a certain glorious god, lighting up the entire Jeta’s Grove, came to me, bowed, stood to one side,
sn2.20:7.3: and recited these verses in my presence.” The Buddha then repeated the verses in full.
sn2.20:13.1: When he said this, Venerable Ānanda said to the Buddha,
sn2.20:13.2: “Sir, that god must surely have been Anāthapiṇḍika.
sn2.20:13.3: For the householder Anāthapiṇḍika was devoted to Venerable Sāriputta.”
sn2.20:13.4: “Good, good, Ānanda. You’ve reached the logical conclusion, as far as logic goes.
sn2.20:13.5: For that was indeed the god Anāthapiṇḍika.”
